newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Reed-Elsevier makes U.S. science deal.
newsitem.headline: Reed-Elsevier makes U.S. science deal.

text.p: Reed Elsevier said on Monday it planned a $320 million public offer for MDL Information Systems Inc. in a deal expected to further strengthen the Anglo-Dutch group's lucrative science publishing business.

Reed Elsevier said its Elsevier Science Inc unit would offer $32 a share for California-based MDL, a supplier of scientific information management systems, under terms unanimously approved by the boards of both companies.
The Anglo-Dutch group said it would use part of its cash balance of more than one billion pounds ($1.6 billion) to pay for MDL.
It said the planned acquisition would bring together the leading provider of scientific information with the leading provider of systems to manage and analyse such data.

MDL's software systems, databases and services help customers in the chemical, pharmaceutical and biotechnology industries to manage, analyse and communicate high volumes of research and development material, it said.
The U.S. company made a pre-tax profit of $11 million in the year to March 31, 1996 on revenues of $62 million.
In February it signed a deal worth several million dollars over three years to supply software and services to British-based Glaxo Wellcome Plc, the world's biggest pharmaceutical company.
Reed Elsevier had revenues of 3.38 billion pounds in 1996 of which 553 million came from science publishing, making it the world's biggest player in this field.
Science publishing is Reed Elsevier's most lucrative business, generating pre-tax profits of 231 million pounds -- a profit margin of 41.8 percent.
Elsevier Science publishes over 1,200 scientific journals and plans to start delivering them through an online database connection this year under the name of Science Direct.
Reed Elsevier co-chairman Herman Bruggink said MDL's products enhanced the productivity and speed of scientific research and were a good strategic fit with Elsevier Science.
"There are considerable opportunities, particularly in an online environment, to add further value to the customers of both MDL and Elsevier Science through the electronic linkage of data," he said.
Board member Paul Vlek told Reuters that MDL would start making a positive contribution to the group's earnings from 1998.
Analysts welcomed the deal, saying MDL would mesh well with Elsevier's existing science publishing business and give an extra push to its plans for electronic distribution.
"In terms of multiples of sales and profits the (purchase sum) is pretty substantial...but I think the synergy advantages will justify that," said Patrick Wollenberg of Rabo Securities.

Jeff Meys of ABN AMRO Hoare Govett said Reed Elsevier planned to pay 32 times MDL's historic earnings before interest and tax which might seem high for a publishing company but was a reasonable multiple in the information technology sector.
He applauded Reed Elsevier's patience in waiting for the right acquisition candidate to come along.
"With the money they were sitting on, any acquisition would have been earnings enhancing...but waiting for the things to come along you really want is good management," he said.
On the Amsterdam bourse Elsevier shares closed 0.10 lower at 28.80 guilders while the main market index fell 1.7 percent.

In London trade Reed International shares fell 23 pence to 10.80 pounds. In morning Nasdaq trade in New York MDL shares were up $13.875 at $31.125 after closing at $17.25 on Friday before the Reed Elsevier bid was announced. ($ = 0.623 British Pounds)
